Minister, will you advise the Senate of actions taken by Australian authorities in relation to the suspected French terrorist recently removed from Australia? And, if you have time, Minister, can you also outline how the capacity of Australia's law enforcement agencies to fight terrorism and other transnational crimes has been strengthened over recent times?

âI thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for what is a very important and timely question. Indeed, recent events serve as a timely reminder that we cannot be complacent about the security of this nation. In Sydney yesterday, the Australian Federal Police, ASIO and the New South Wales Police undertook joint operations in connection with the arrest in France of a French national on terrorism related offences. The Australian government was advised by French authorities on 22 September that Mr Willie Brigitte, a French national, who reportedly participated in military training in Pakistan and Afghanistan, may have entered Australia in May 2003. I can confirm that Mr Brigitte entered Australia on 16 May on a tourist visa. On 7 October this year, further information was provided by French authorities, who expressed concern that Mr Brigitte might be in Australia in connection with terrorist related activity. Mr Brigitte was taken into custody in an immigration detention centre on 9 October for breaching the conditions of his visa. He was returned to France, under escort, on 17 October this year. On his return to France he was questioned and is now being held in custody in accordance with French law in connection with possible terrorism related offences. The Australian government has reacted swiftly and decisively in relation to this serious matter.

âThe opposition might not think this is serious, but I can tell you that the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Bob Carr, certainly thought it was serious. As both Mr Carr and the Attorney-General have said, the response by Australian authorities has been swift and effective. Indeed, both have applauded the way that state and federal authorities have acted together in unison in relation to what is a serious issue. As investigations are ongoing, I will not discuss the result of actions taken under the warrants, but I can say they were directed against a number of people who, it was believed, could have material relating to Mr Brigitte's presence in Australia. I understand, furthermore, that the Leader of the Opposition has been briefed on this matter.

answer.para: Senator Sandy Macdonald raises serious issues in relation to what else we have done to enhance the capacity of our agencies to protect Australia's security and interests. We have committed more than $1.8 billion to national security initiatives since 11 September 2001 and the Bali bombings. This has included additional resources to ASIO, ASIS, the AFP, Defence and special forces. It is timely to remember that just over a week ago, the Attorney-General, Mr Ruddock, launched the National Threat Assessment Centreâa keystone in our enhanced security arrangementsâand announced more than $50 million worth of funding to be spent over five years to enhance the operation of this important centre. It will run 24 hours a day to identify and issue assessments of threats to Australia, Australians and Australian interests, both here and abroad. It will work closely with our intelligence counterparts. The Howard government has introduced many other initiatives to enhance the security arrangements for the protection of this nation. It is something we cannot be complacent about, especially given recent events.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Minister Hill, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: is the minister aware that under international law, the Geneva Convention, there are three occupying powers in Iraq: the US, the UK and Australia? Is the minister aware that at the most recent donors conference in Madrid two of those three occupying powers were represented at ministerial levelâthe United States by Secretary of State Colin Powell and US Treasury Secretary Snow and the UK by cabinet level Secretary of State for International Development, Hilary Benn? Minister, why was Australia the only occupying power not to be represented at ministerial level at the international conference on the reconstruction of Iraq in Madrid?
âThe issue of whether Australia is an occupying power is open for debate.

âWhy did Senator Bolkus say Australia is, and Poland is not? There were four parties in the coalition of the willing which had forces in Iraq during the time of the removal of Saddam Hussein. In any event, it will surprise Senator Bolkus, no doubt, that Mr Downer was in Australia because of two very important visitors. The government believed that in these circumstancesâthe unique occasion of the visit of the President of the United States and the President of the People's Republic of Chinaâthe foreign minister should be here. I understand that he was ably represented in Madrid by Mrs Gallus, who looks after aid matters. The contribution by Australia is, of course, through the aid program.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was this decision by Australia not to be represented at ministerial level at the Madrid conference taken because the Howard government had already decided only to contribute a maximum of $20 million at such conference in Madrid? Is it also a fact that, following the military action in Afghanistan in which Australia participated militarily in late 2001-early 2002, Australia again failed to be represented at ministerial level at the subsequent Tokyo donors conference for the economic reconstruction of Afghanistan?

âOn the issue of `occupying power', I remind Senator Bolkus that UN Security Council resolution 1483 names only the US and UK as occupying powers in Iraq. On the issue of Australia's participation in donor conferences, I think what is important is that Australia is prepared to make a significant contribution. As I have indicated, Australia's contribution now totals over $120 million, which I think is a significant contribution of taxpayers' money towards a very good cause.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Ian Macdonald. Will the minister inform the Senate of the steps taken by the government to protect Australia's live animal export trade?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âSenator McGauran and all senators will be pleased to see the resolution of the incident with the Cormo Express and the fact that the sheep are now being offloaded in an Eritrean port. The government has always been very keen to protect the $1 billion livestock export trade that is so vital to Australian producers, and particularly to country Australiaâ9,000 jobs are involved in the live animal export trade. But there are community expectations and expectations of the government that the livestock trade be conducted humanely. In recent years, the government has joined with industry to ensure that the welfare of animals in the trade is treated with extreme importance. The government established the Independent Reference Group, chaired by the Commonwealth Chief Veterinary Officer, some time ago. All the recommendations of that group on the live animal trade have been, or are being, implemented.

answer.para: As well, Senator McGauran will be interested to know that an action plan for the livestock export industry has been developed jointly between the government and the industry. Work on that is already well under way and many of the outcomes have been implemented. The government has suspended or cancelled the export licences of companies that do not meet the strict animal welfare requirements. We have also had very direct contact with relevant veterinary authorities in overseas markets. Our involvement in that is influencing a change in animal welfare outcomes, which have vastly improvedâalthough as a nation we have to be very sensitive to the cultural differences of our trading partners. AQIS will not be issuing any further export certifications for livestock to Saudi Arabia until there is a formal agreement in place with the Saudi authorities to manage the trade on a more predictable and transparent basis. The Australian government is focusing on the need to ensure that there is no repeat of the incident.

Senators will be interested to know that the independent panel set up to conduct an investigation into Australia's livestock export industry with particular reference to the Cormo Express incident will be chaired by Dr John Keniry, the past president of the Australian Chamber of Commerce.

Overall, the cost to Australia will be considerable. The cost of doing nothing, as the opposition seemed to want to do, would have been catastrophic to Australia. I am disappointed that all the way through this Cormo Express incident the opposition have not had any decent suggestions to make on what should happen. I congratulate Mr Truss and his officials on the way they have handled this and the arrangements they have made with the Eritrean government. Their hard work and their proactivity is in marked contrast to the negativity and political point scoring and carping that has come from the opposition. That is distressing because this is a very valuable industry to Australia and one which Australia will certainly be encouraging into the future.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Hill as Minister for Defence and in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware of reports in the Australian and US media citing Australian Brigadier General Stephen Meekin, who said that the aluminium tubes which were used as evidence of Iraq's attempts to reconstitute its nuclear weapons program were `innocuous' and `were used for rockets'? Does the minister recall statements by the foreign minister that `Iraq's attempted acquisition of very specific types of aluminium tubes'âthis was said on 17 September 2002âmay be part of Iraq's attempts to acquire equipment that could be used in uranium enrichment? Given that Brigadier General Meekin is from your department, can you advise the Senate who is right: the brigadier or the foreign minister?

âI did notice those press reports and I sought some advice on the matter and have been advised, for the benefit of honourable senators, that Brigadier Meekin is the commander of the joint captured materiel exploitation centre, which has the mission of examining and locating Iraq's conventional weapons and is only peripherally involved in the investigation of Iraq's WMD programs. I am told that Brigadier Meekin spoke only about Iraq's conventional military capabilities. Unfortunately the journalist inaccurately and wrongly used the comments to make assertions about Iraq's nuclear programs. I am told that the brigadier made no judgment on the suitability or otherwise of aluminium tubes for Iraq's nuclear weapons program.

âI have a supplementary question, Mr President. I note that the minister has cut the brigadier loose, but perhaps the minister could confirm to the Senate, given that the previous claim that Iraq had attempted to source uranium from Niger was proven false, that this is the case. Will the government now formally retract its prewar statement to the Australian parliament and people that allegations concerning both aluminium tubes and the importation of uranium from Africa were evidence of the reconstitution of Iraq's nuclear weapons capability? Isn't it time, Minister, for you to front up and say that was wrong?

âDeterminations in relation to the aluminium tubes I understand have not authoritatively been concluded. Therefore, in accordance with the urgings of the Kay review, it is suggested that we should await the final outcome of the scientific examinations in that regard. In relation to the importation of uranium from Africa, there is no doubt there was a time in which Iraq did import uranium from Africa and did have an active nuclear weapons program. In relation to the particular time in question in relation to Niger, it seems that, yes, as Senator Faulkner has said, at that time uranium was not being imported into Iraq. Questions about WMD in Iraq are still ongoing and still being analysed by the Iraq Survey Group and we hope to get a final report in due course. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the government acknowledge that there are numerous independent reports indicating that the Chinese government continues to detain, torture and in some cases kill its citizens on the basis of their beliefs, and that in particular Falun Gong practitioners, Tibetan monks and Christians continue to be subjected to severe persecution? Does the government acknowledge that those practices are contrary to fundamental human rights, including freedom of speech, religion and association? Given the Prime Minister's assertion to the media that his one-on-one discussions with President Hu `covered all the major aspects of our relationship', did the Prime Minister raise in his one-on-one discussions with the Chinese President any of these fundamental human rights issuesâgiven that he did not raise them in his public speech in the House of Representatives last Friday?

âI answered a similar question from Senator Harradine a few weeks ago, although it did not specifically relate to what Mr Howard said to the Chinese President; I think it related to what Senator Harradine believed the Prime Minister should say. The point is nevertheless the same, and that is that Australia does have a human rights dialogue with China. We think this is a useful and effective means through which we can put our views to China on human rights issues and hopefully influence China towards better practices in that regard. No-one disputes the importance of human rights; the issue is how best a country such as Australia can influence China in the right direction. We do believe that offering positive reinforcement as well as negative from time to time is the right direction, and the opening up of China that is occurring is consistent with a better human rights direction. It is easy to sit in the Senate and criticise. What the Australian government is interested in doing is looking for useful ways in which we can positively influence a better outcome. What the Australian government does is take those opportunities as they present.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Surely a one-on-one discussion with the President of China presents an opportunity to raise these issues. Given that the Prime Minister said that those one-on-one discussions covered `all the major aspects of our relationship', does his refusal or unwillingness to raise these issues in that one-on-one discussion indicate that the Australian government does not believe that our concern about these fundamental human rights is a major aspect of our relationship with China?

âAs the honourable senator said, it was a one-on-one discussion, and I am not sure what exactly was said in the one-on-one discussion. Certainly, the Australian government recognises that these are fundamental human rights and that it is important that we seek to influence each other towards better practices. As I have said, the Australian governmentâparticularly through the human rights dialogue, but also by taking other opportunitiesâseeks to influence China in a better direction in this regard. We think there have been signs of improvement and that credit should be given where it is due.

âMy question is to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Trade. Can the minister confirm that in discussions last week the Prime Minister told President Bush that local content rules for new media are now up for negotiation under the free trade agreement? Doesn't this represent a significant departure from the position under the Singapore free trade agreement where Australia reserved the right to take any future measures in relation to cultural and creative industries? Why does the government believe that it is more important to protect Australian culture against programming from Singapore rather than the US?
âI am aware of the outcome of the Singapore agreement, and that was applauded by the cultural sector, as I recall. It may even have been given some credit by the opposition.
âI believe so.
âIt was? That is very good.
âWhat about the US?

âIn relation to the US, I think it is a signal of the Australian government's attitude to this important issue. If you look at what we have been able to achieve in the Singapore agreement, that demonstrates to all the Australian community that we regard this issue as important and that we can achieve good outcomes. In relation to the US, I would repeat what Mr Vaile has said: that we will ensure that our capacity to support `Australian cultural and national identity, including in audiovisual media, is not watered down in the negotiations'. The government is having wide-ranging discussions with the US on issues affected by the FTA negotiations and has long signalled that these discussions will include the audiovisual sector. However, the government recognises the importance of maintaining cultural objectives and has confirmed this in its statement of public objectives for the FTA with the US. The position has been in place since day one and has not changed.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the government accept that the adoption of a `standstill' provision, which simply preserves existing regulations, will not ensure the provision of Australian programming as technology evolves? Will the government give an undertaking to put the national interest above the Prime Minister's political interests and walk away from the FTA at the cost of selling out Australia's creative and cultural industries?

âWith respect, that was a strange supplementary because obviously the Australian national interest drives the Australian national government. What I am saying to the honourable senator is that, if you look at what has been achieved in the Singapore agreement, it should give you confidence that what will be achieved in the US agreement will be equally successful. The government has made its attitude clear on the importance of these cultural values and, as I said, stands by those previous statements.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Hill. Is the minister aware of the Prime Minister's comments last week concerning the fate of two Australians, David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib, currently illegally detained by the United States in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba? Can the minister explain what exactly the Prime Minister meant by `it would be good if that process could be brought forward'? Does this mean that the government have finally agreed to seek the repatriation of these citizens in order that they can be afforded the basic legal rights that we as a society are supposed to uphold or does it mean that they will be fast-tracked through a kangaroo court process?

âJust in case there is any doubt, the government certainly does not accept that they are being illegally detained, but it is true that the issues were raised with President Bush during his visit last week. The Prime Minister indicated that he would like to see the military commission process brought forward. The government has secured significant commitments by the US government to ensure that any military commissioned trial of Mr Hicks is fair and transparent. These commitments are in addition to legal rights already afforded under military commission orders and instructions such as the presumption of innocence and a standard of proof beyond reasonable doubt. We understand why they are being held as the war against terror is ongoing. Nevertheless, the government is anxious that matters relating to their future be concluded as quickly as possible, and as can be seen from the representations that the Prime Minister made last week, bearing in mind that they are in US custody, we are putting that sentiment into practice.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that, according to the US military order of November 2001, no matter what conclusions the military tribunal comes to, the final determination of the fate of Mr Hicks and Mr Habib will be made by the US President? Given that the President of the United States announced to the world's media that he considers all detainees at Guantanamo Bay to be `bad men', is the government comfortable that the two Australian citizens will face an unbiased judgment?

âYes, we are comfortable because of the efforts we have made to ensure that that is the case. This is in relation to Mr Hicks. In relation to Mr Habib, there has not been a decision yet as to whether he is eligible for a military commission trial. But, in relation to Mr Hicks, efforts are being made to ensure that the trial is fair. As I recall, it is before a panel of judges. He will have legal representation. Through the representations of the Australian Attorney-General, we are satisfied that it will be a transparent process that meets the standards of acceptable justice. It is not a civil process; it is a military process, I concede that. He is being held in detention by the US military. He was captured on the battlefield, but he will be dealt with fairly. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Why were the negotiations with the Eritrean government on the fate of the sheep stranded aboard the MV Cormo Express kept secret from the Australian people, the parliament and the industry groups with a significant stake in Australia's live export industry? Can the minister advise whether the $1 million inducement offered to the Eritreans was offered to each of the other nations involved in the negotiations on the fate of the sheep? Will costs associated with the management of this fiasco be passed to Australian farmers as a result of the government's new live export levy? What costs will be borne by taxpayers? Is it true that the total cost of this fiasco will far exceed $10 million?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe MOU with Eritrea was actually signed on 16 October, but final acceptance of the arrangement depended upon a veterinary inspection by the Eritreans, which took place on the ship in the harbour on 23 October. The unloading started on 24 October. Senator O'Brien asks why this was kept secret. As all senators would know, there was an influence trying to stop Australia unloading these sheep. We had a lot of discussions with a lot of different countries, but we were never able to achieve as much as we did with the Eritreans. We wanted to complete the arrangement with the Eritreans, which was that they would have their vets inspect the sheep before the unloading started. I have given Senator O'Brien the dates. If you call that secret, that is the answer. I would hardly call it too secret.

answer.para: Senator O'Brien asked whether the $1 million was offered to other countries we spoke to. I think Mr Truss made it quite clear at any number of press conferences that the Australian government was prepared to help the countries that might take them on board in the way of transport, feeding and moving them around in the country in which they actually ended up. Whether it was $1 million, certainly the offer was made to many countries. Senator O'Brien further asked whether the Australian farmers will pay a levy. That is certainly the decision of the government. That has been discussed at great length with the industry, and the industry are supportive of that. It will be a levy on exports of animals, so I guess that will be paid by the farmers involved. It will not be paid by the Australian public. I guess there will be some taxpayer money involved in the work of officials, but it will be relatively minor.

Senator O'Brien asked whether the expense is going to be much more than $10 million. Senator O'Brien, at the moment I can tell you that the expenses are about $9.5 million from the government so far. A lot of it will be collected from the levy. There is about $2 million from the MLA, and that will be paid for by the industry. The final bill is not yet available. It will be some time yet before the final bill is determined. I am not aware of how much more than $10 million it is going to beâif it is going to be any moreâbut we will certainly keep the Senate informed.

Senator O'Brien, all of these things do show great credit on the department. We inherited a situation that was not of the government's making. I can only again give absolute credit to Mr Truss and his officials for the outcome. It is with regret, Senator O'Brien, that I say it was in stark contrast to your approach and the approach of your party who have really sought to make some political capital out of what was a matter with very serious national implications. If you had had a solution, we would have been very pleased to hear it, but through all of this unhappy saga we have had no positive solutions from the Labor Partyâjust this nitpicking, carping opposition's political point scoring.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I have a supplementary question. Does the memorandum that the minister referred to with the Eritrean government preclude the export of the Cormo Express sheep to other countriesâincluding, for example, Saudi Arabia? Will the government release the memorandum revealing the full details of its arrangement with the Eritrean government? And, if it will not, why will it not release that memorandum?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe arrangement was entered into to provide food for the Eritrean people, said to be amongst the poorest on our planet. We are happy that the sheep will go to that end.
âCan you guarantee that? They won't go to Saudi Arabia?
âSenator Sherry asks if I can guarantee it. No, I cannot, but that is the government's intention.

âSenator, I certainly cannot give a guarantee. I am not even the relevant minister. I am representing the minister. In relation to the terms of the MOU, Senator O'Brien, I am afraid that I personally do not have details of it. I have not personally seen it. I will ask Mr Truss for a copy of the MOU. Again, I cannot speak for Mr Truss, but I would imagine there would be no objection to releasing the terms of the MOU. I think it is a fairly public document. Australia is fairly open in all of these sorts of things, but I will ask Mr Truss and get an answer for you on that.

âMy question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator Minchin. Will the minister advise the Senate of the importance of prioritising government spending to deliver sound economic management? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

âI thank Senator Scullion for that good question. Our government has been very successful in the area of our fiscal policy and our budget strategy. Part of that is based on our very strong approach to the control of government spending. It is for that reason that we were able to do three things in the last budget that almost no other government in the world is able to do: we were able to meet our essential spending requirements, particularly in defence and national security; we were able to give a $2.4 billion per annum tax cut; and we were able to keep the budget in surplus. That is probably unique in the developed world. It is in very stark contrast to the management style of the Labor Party when in government. In their last five years in government, they ran up deficits totalling $65 billion.

answer.para: It appears that there has been absolutely no change in the approach of the Labor Party to this question of responsible budget strategy. They go around attacking us for not spending enough money in almost every area of government, and the Leader of the Opposition goes around promising to spend a whole lot more money in order to prop up his leadership. We have had a whole series of promises from the opposition. They have promised higher GP rebates, more Austudy, more doctors, more nurses, more teachers, a coastguard, an office of national security, a department of homeland security, a commissioner for children, an Indigenous support fund, a community engagement fund, a better cities program, a student wellbeing pilotâand the list goes on and on. They have even promised a school canteen task force.

talk.start.para: âWe have got some election promises now, have we?

âThe problem with all this is that we are still probably a year away from an election. But, by their own admission, Labor have already racked up promises totalling $6.5 billion over the forward estimates in new spending promises, and the election campaign has not even started. You can imagine what they are going to promise to spend when the campaign starts.

answer.para: Of course, they do understand that you can no longer pay for your promises by racking up deficitsâat least they have learnt that lessonâbut what they are now going to do to pay for all their promises is whack up taxes. They criticise us for high taxes, but taxes are going to be a lot higher under them. In the words of their finance spokesman, Mr McMullan, Labor are promising to tax families with new children by removing tax rebates provided through the baby bonus; they are going to increase fuel excise for rural and regional Australians by axing the fuel sales grant scheme; they are going to tax motorists with a new ethanol tax; they are going to raise $800 million through an increase in the superannuation surcharge; they are going to increase the diesel excise for the mining industry through $400 million in cuts to the diesel rebate; they are going to slug Australian companies $270 million by opposing the reform of international tax arrangements; they are still promising to introduce a new Australia-wide payroll tax, a tax on jobs; and, of course, there are extra taxes on foreign workers, redundancies and share dividends.

They have the temerity to go around criticising us, saying that taxes are too high under our government, but every Australian knows that, under a Crean Labor government, taxes will be a lot higher than they are under our government to pay for this incredible array of new spending promises. Mr McMullan has now shown his hand by saying where the taxes will be increased. They did it to the Australian people after the 1993 federal election when they made a whole lot of spending promises and then came in and increased taxes right across the board in the 1993 budget. The Labor Party have not changed their spots. They are still the party of tax and spend.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Trade. Can the minister confirm that in previous free trade agreements, such as that negotiated with Chile, the US has negotiated transition periods of up to 12 years for improved access to its agricultural markets? Can the minister also confirm that, under the latest offer, only 20 per cent of the US agricultural market will be opened up to Australian farmers during the first year of the agreement? Given the Prime Minister's concession last week that he would accept improvements in access that would `build up over time', how long will Australian beef, sugar and dairy producers have to wait to obtain the benefit of any free trade agreement?

âThis is really part of the negotiation. As I understand, it is not unusual for there to be transitional periods and for benefits to be phased in. Obviously it is very important to Australia to get a good agricultural outcome from the free trade agreement. It is probably the area in which there is the greatest opportunity to expand our exports to the United States and thus create wealth for the benefit of all Australians. But I do not think it is appropriate during the course of negotiations to be in effect determining the outcome. That is what the negotiation is all about.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of comments by the National Farmers Federation that transition times of more than 10 years for market access are `way too long for the free trade agreement to be effective for Australian agriculture'? Does the government accept the position of the National Farmers Federation that transition times should be between one and five years at the most? Will the government give an undertaking to put the national interest above the Prime Minister's political interest? Will he support the NFF position and walk away from the free trade agreement if it comes at the cost of selling out Australia's farmers?

âI do find this astonishing. The Labor Party was in government for 13 years. Did it try to get a free trade agreement with the United States to improve the lot of Australian farmers? Did it try once in 13 years? No, it did not. Furthermore, it condemned even the principle of it; it argued against bilateral attempts to open up markets for the benefit of Australian farmers. Here is an instance where the current Australian government, under Mr Howard, is endeavouring to open up US markets to Australian farmers. What the Labor Party ought to do is get behind the government in this attempt, because by doing so it will be benefiting Australia rather than trying to make cheap points. Nobody appreciates a Labor Party that just carpsâcontinually complains, continually acts so negatively. This is an opportunity for both sides of parliament to get behind the opportunity that has been presented, get a better deal for Australian farmers and therefore benefit all Australians.

âMy question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. The Prime Minister is on the record as stating he was `prepared to be flexible toward US interests' with regard to trade and audiovisual services. Given that local content rules for television are in legislation and given the regulation of GM foods and the PBS are also in legislation, can the government assure the Senate that the government will not agree to any proposals that require legislative change without a clear statement that such requirements are subject to parliamentary approval? Further, can the minister assure the Senate that the ability of future parliaments to raise standards in respect of local content and TV, GM foods, the PBS and quarantine standards will not be compromised or traded off?
âI have answered questions on this subject before, and basicallyâ
âNo, you did not.
âYes, I have, on each of the aspects. What I have said isâ
âIt is Senator Cherry's call, not Senator Sherry's call.

âthe Australian government have gone into this negotiation because there is an opportunity through freer trade to build Australian exports, to build Australian wealth and therefore to benefit all Australiansâbut we will do so consistent with a number of protections and values that we believe are important. There are values within our health system in relation to medicines that we will want to preserve. There are a number of ways in which that can be done. But we obviously want to preserve the principle; it is a very important part of the Australian health system. I already said in question time today there are cultural values that we will seek to preserve as well. The issue of Australian quarantine has never been in question. We will never allow Australia's quarantine rules to be put into question.

answer.para: These are basic principles. But within basic principles there is the opportunity to negotiate an agreement that can bring benefit to Australia through an expansion of trade, and that is what this negotiation is all about. In the same way that I urge the Labor Party to for once get on board and be constructive and positive about this process, I would suggest it also to the Australian Democrats, because we have already seen in recent times that it is possible to get benefits out of such agreementsâthrough the agreement we have achieved with Thailand and through the agreement we have achieved with Singapore. There is clearly a huge potential for benefit in an agreement with the United States and ultimately there will be a benefit in an agreement with China. This is a government that looks to expand Australia's trade opportunities because that is the best way to create wealth and bring advantage, as I said, to all Australians.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister, for that complete non-answer to my question. My question was about whether the government intended to trade off the capacity of this parliament or future parliaments to regulate in these areas. The minister would be aware that, under the North American Free Trade Area agreement investor-state dispute resolution mechanisms, the Canadian government has to pay out millions of dollars in compensation to US corporations as a result of insisting on domestic regulation. Can the minister assure the Senate that the parliament's ability to legislate on matters into the future will not be affected by compensation claims from US corporations as a result of any compromises or any commitments given by the government in this free trade agreement?

âThe executive cannot trade off the legislative responsibility and capacity of this Senate and the House. We have distinct responsibilities in this process. The executive have voluntarily agreed, as the honourable senator knows, to a treaties process thatâwithin the consideration of a treaty document by the parliamentâallows for inquiries, allows for examinations and allows for public interest statements. But ultimately the executive cannot override the legislation within which the executive operate.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister, and it follows on from an answer he gave to an earlier question from Senator Bolkus in question time when the minister stated that Australia's position as an occupying power in Iraq was debatable. Can the minister confirm that Mr Howard was asked at a press conference on 10 April:

quote.para: Will Australia formally be an occupying power in Iraq? And what legal responsibilities would such a role bring?

question.para: Can the minister confirm that Mr Howard, in response, said:

quote.para: Well, we would be there in terms of the conditions of the Geneva Convention, I think, of 1907.

question.para: Can the minister also confirm that in an interview with Paul Murray on radio 6PR earlier this year, on 17 April, the Prime Minister was asked by Mr Murray:

quote.para: Are we now what is termed `an occupying power' under the Geneva Convention?

question.para: And the Prime Minister responded:

quote.para: We have the obligation of an occupying power under the Geneva Convention.

question.para: Does the minister still think this issue is debatable, or was the Prime Minister right when he twice admitted earlier this year that Australia is an occupying power?

talk.start.para: âI do not think that Senator Faulkner was listening to my earlier answer. I said to Senator Bolkus that whether we are an occupying power is an arguable pointâ

âand it is arguable. Subsequent to the Prime Minister's statement, the UN Security Council resolution named only two countries, the US and the UK, as occupying powers in Iraq. But that does not mean, of course, that we do not comply with the Geneva convention or voluntarily accept responsibilities under it. The point I am making is, whether we are obliged to accept those responsibilities or we voluntarily accept them, we nevertheless accept them, so that in practice there is little difference. I also remind Senator Faulkner that, although in terms of the Security Council resolution we may not be an occupying power, we are complying fully with the relevant obligations under all international law as a member of the Coalition Provisional Authority.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Prime Minister has admitted that Australia is an occupying power, perhaps the minister can now explain why Australia sent such low-level representation to the Madrid conference. Given his excuses earlier in question time and given the Prime Minister's statement, perhaps he can now explain to us what the real reason was for such a low level of representation at the Madrid conference.

âI must say, Senator Macdonald, I cannot see the point either. It is a technical legal question as to whether Australia is an occupying power. What I have said is that, even if it is not, it accepts the responsibilities. It is there to make a positive contribution, particularly to the safety and security of the population and occupying forces, to the availability of food, shelter and medical care, and to the administration of the occupied territory for the benefit of its populationâin other words, all the responsibilities of an occupying power. We are doing it within Iraq through our defence forces. We are doing it through Australian experts who are in the CPA, including those in fields such as agriculture, health, water, sanitation, economic policy, legal affairs, petroleum and institutional development. We are doing it through such people as Trevor Flugge, who is playing a leading role in agriculture. We are doing it in aid by contributing over $120 million. In relation to Chris Gallus, I think she is an excellent parliamentary secretary, and I am sure that she represented Australia's interests well. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson. Will the minister outline to the Senate how job seekers and families are benefiting as a result of the government's responsible economic policies? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI would like to thank Senator Brandis for this very important question. It is a very important question following on from the question that was asked of Senator Minchin earlier and Senator Minchin's explanation and discussion about Labor's alternative policies. When we came to government in 1996 we inherited a $96 billion debt. It was costing Australians $4 billion in interest alone. They probably do not like to hear thatâ$4 billion in interest alone. The Labor Party were living beyond their means and beyond Australia's means. They were irresponsible. As I have said and I will say over and over again in this chamber, they were borrowing from the next generation to pay for short-term gain. That is what they were doing: borrowing from the next generation, not for deep infrastructure but to actually pay for short-term gain. Record high interest rates were eroding family household budgets and, coupled with the recession that we had to have, there were nearly one million people unemployed. You could not expect anything else from a party that cannot balance the books without relying on debt. Senator Minchin has explained already how they would be heading in that direction if they were ever to get their hands on the government levers again.

answer.para: Since we came into office we have delivered effective and targeted policies to increase the prospects of job seekers finding employment and to increase the wellbeing of families. The fairer tax system has not only decreased effective marginal tax ratesâtherefore putting more money in Australian workers' pocketsâbut also increased government family assistance by about $2 billion a year. Since March 1996 we have increased average real disposable incomes of low-income households by eight per centâinstead of being down at five per cent between 1992 and 1996 when, I remind honourable senators, Labor was in government.

We have replaced 12 payments for family assistance with three payments, providing around two million Australian families with additional assistance. We have made it easier for parents to make the decision to go back to work by spending more than $7 billion on child care in the first six years in office. This is a 70 per cent increase in real terms over and above what Labor spent in its last six years in office. We have produced 190,000 additional places since we came into office. With regard to the baby bonus, we will put $170 million into the budgets of households with a new firstborn child this financial year. Labor claims that most of this finance is going to higher income families. Labor is wrong. In the 2001-02 income year, the majority of payments wentâ

talk.start.para: âI reckon it would pay for the Labor Party to listen to what I am saying.
âOrder! Minister, ignore the interjections. I remind speakers on my left that it is disorderly to interrupt the speaker when they are on their feet.

âThey do not want to hear this, because Mr McMullan has been saying the opposite. In the 2001-02 income year, the majority of payments went to families with taxable incomes of $20,000 or less. Over $39 millionâor 81 per cent of the benefits paidâwent to these families. Labor say it is going to high-income families, but the data shows in the last year for which we have figures that the majority of people had incomes of $20,000 or less. The opposition said they will remove itâand that will be another tax on families.

answer.para: If you look at the family tax benefit, under Labor when parents underestimated their incomes they were not eligible for a top-up. Under the Howard government, 680,000 families in 2001-02 received a top-up of their family tax benefit. Together with other assistance the Howard government will provide an estimated $19 billion to families this financial year. I remind honourable senators that one of benefits to families has been the assistance with their health insurance payments. One of the other things we have done is taken real action to reduce unemployment. I remind honourable senators that the last time unemployment was below six per cent, interest rates were below five per cent and the CPI was below three per cent was 35 years ago. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister provide the Senate with more information in relation to the effect on Australian families of the government's policies?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âWe have created 1.2 million new jobs since 1996. That has had an enormous effect on families. As I said before, unemployment is now 5.8 per centâthe lowest level since 1990 and well below Labor's peak of 10.7 per cent. Long-term unemployment has also dropped since we came into office by 17.6 per cent in the last five years. We are now spending $2.2 billion annually to support more than 380,000 young people through the youth allowance, enabling them and encouraging them to take up training and to study. We are delivering a real difference for Australian job seekers and their families. The Howard government have responsible economic policies that are benefiting us not only now but also into the future, rather than relying on debt, like the Labor Party did, to fund short-term irresponsible fixes. As Senator Minchin said, they are heading down the same track now.

âMy question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for Defence. Can the minister confirm that under current arrangements some of our most skilled ADF personnel, including the special forces, pilots and submariners, are suffering significant financial penalties as a result of their superannuation arrangements? Don't the SAS who served in Iraq have their take-home pay discounted by 40 per cent when determining their superannuation entitlements, leaving them thousands of dollars out of pocket when they retire? Hasn't Defence agreed that this anomaly should be immediately fixed and that qualifications and skill based allowances in ADF should be superannuated? Wasn't a submission seeking approval for this change sent to the government in June? Has the government made a decision? If not, why not?
âThere isâ
âYou haven't had time to read your brief.
âI don't need the brief. I prefer to rely on my own memory.
âOrder! Minister, ignore the interjections.
âThere is an issue as to whether allowances that have not been superannuable in the past should be. That is of course at additional cost to the budget.
âNo, some allowances are not superannuable; for them to be so will require additional funding. That issue has been raised and is being considered by the government.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was: has the government made a decision in respect of this matter? If not, why not? And can the minister confirm that many of the people affected by this problem are in areas where the ADF is struggling to retain personnel? Aren't there ongoing shortages of pilots and submariners? Hasn't the government's refusal to date to fix the inequity in superannuation treatment served to exacerbate those shortages? Why does the minister continue to dither on a proposal that would fix this anomaly once and for all?

âThere are shortages with some pilots but not others, actually. The issue of incentives to retain or to encourage and increase enrolment in specific areas of the ADF is dealt with in the specific instances where there are shortages, through additional benefits being provided. That is not relevant to this particular matter. This particular matter is about whether certain allowances should receive the extra benefit of being superannuable. As I said, that is at additional cost to the government. It is being considered by the government at the moment and when the government makes a decision, it will announce it. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

âI have some further information in relation to a question Senator Bartlett asked me today about human rights in China. The Prime Minister has indicated to me that he did raise human rights issues with President Hu when he met with him. I am aware that they were raised in the cabinet room discussions in the context of the human rights dialogue and the importance of that dialogue. They were raised by Mr Howard. By my recollection they were also raised by Mr Downer and specific reference was made for that dialogue to provide an opportunity to raise such sensitive issues as human rights in Tibet.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Hill) to questions without notice asked by Senators Conroy and Forshaw today relating to the proposed free trade agreement.

speech.para: Once again we have seen today the government fail to give straight answers to questions about Australia's position on key issues surrounding the free trade agreement. This is the fourth round of talks commencing this week, so it is very important that the Australian public and community have a clear indication from this government of what our objectives are, what we are prepared to give up and what we are not prepared to give up. That is what is at stake.

The government is starting to show worrying signs of backsliding on previous commitments on local content. It has long been clear the US government wanted, in this area, a thing called `standstill'. That is, Australia could retain the existing local content rules for film, radio and television but would trade off the right to either increase local content quotas or apply them to new media in the future as the mechanism for delivering programming changes. Until recently the government appeared to accept the vital importance of retaining the right to regulate local content in new forms of media. Earlier this month Australia's chief negotiator, Stephen Deady, told the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee:

quote.para: ... it certainly is wrong to say that our offer is a standstill offer, because it is not.

speech.para: But the government has shifted ground following the visit by President Bush just last week. Minister Vaile warned that it would not be easy to resist US demands for no local content rules on new forms of delivery. Then the Prime Minister told the President that Australia would accept a more liberal regime to apply to the Internet and other new media. Yet when Senator Hill is asked about it today, what does he say? To use the Prime Minister's current favourite word, flummery is all we got from Senator Hill. The recently concluded Singapore agreement includes the provision:

quote.para: Australia reserves the right to adopt or maintain any measure relating to:
the creative arts(1), cultural heritage(2) and other cultural industries, including audio-visual services, entertainment services and libraries, archives, museums and other cultural services ...

speech.para: If such a protection is deemed necessary in an agreement with Singapore, how can it not be essential in a free trade deal with the United States, the home of the largest film and television production industry in the world?

The other area where backsliding appears to have begun relates to market access. There is no more critical point in these negotiations than this one. Labor maintains that any FTA with the US must deliver significant and tangible benefits to Australian farmers. At the commencement of negotiations, the government committed Australia to seeking the removal of tariff rate quota restrictions on Australian exports to the United States, especially those affecting beef, dairy, sugar, peanuts and cotton. Last week the US Trade Representative, Mr Zoellick, announced in Bangkok that under the latest offer only 21 per cent of US agricultural products would be opened up to competition from Australian producers immediately once the agreement came into effect. Why is this important? In the last two weeks the Prime Minister has proudly announced that the Australia-Thailand Free Trade Agreement had been signed and put out a press release. He said:

quote.para: More than half of Thailand's five thousand tariffs will be eliminated as soon as the Agreement enters into force. Virtually all the remaining tariffs will be eliminated by 2010.

speech.para: Let me read that again:

quote.para: Virtually all the remaining tariffs will be eliminated by 2010.

speech.para: When the agreement is announced you get a press release from the Prime Minister so that the Prime Minister gets lots of nice kudos and lots of support publicly, and that is what is in the papers the next day. But, when you get to see what the agreement actually says, you see that the Prime Minister failed to mention the following facts. For beef, pork, butter, cheese, potatoes and sugar, it will be not by 2010 but by 2020 before we get free access. For some of our biggest exports it will be 2020. The killer, though, is that for milk, cream and skim milk powder, the year we get free access will be 2025. We have a Prime Minister who says on the one hand:

quote.para: Virtually all the remaining tariffs will be eliminated by 2010.

speech.para: On the other hand, the tariffs on our biggest exports into the area will not be eliminated until 2025. This is a government that you cannot trust. It says one thing and does another. That is why the cultural industries, the farmers, the environmentalists and the labour unions all want to know, Prime Minister, what the deal is. They want to know what is on the table and what is not on the table. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âListening to Senator Conroy speak you would think he represents an opposition that knows what their position is on the free trade agreement, and they clearly do not. It might be helpful to Senator Conroy and his colleagues to take a tip from the lead of the state premiersâall Labor Party premiersâwho last week put out a joint statement in support of the Australian government's position in pursuit of an FTA with the United States.
âWhy didn't you mention that, Stephen?
âI'm supporting it.

âSenator Conroy, whether or not you are supporting it is not very clear at all. It is a shame that Senator Cook is not here this week because whilst he may hold his punches on whether he supports wholeheartedly the FTA, Senator Cook does have a broader understanding of trade issues than some of his colleagues.

speech.para: Australia has a very strong commitment to the multilateral system, and we show that through the WTO, through APEC and in some other ways as well. We believe very strongly in looking to those areas of advantage to Australian manufacturers and farmersânot just farmers but everybodyâand we come to trade negotiations in the main with very clean hands. We have a very strong export culture. You can see that in the free trade agreement with Thailand that was announced last week. That provides a market opportunity of an additional 63 million people for Australian manufacturers and primary producers. The negotiations were concluded with the fastest-growing economyâand a stand-out economyâin South-East Asia, Thailand. We feel very strongly about these bilateral arrangements. We are very pleased we were able to get a free trade agreement with Singapore. That is why we believe very strongly in the free trade agreement with the United States.

Why would you think for one moment the Australian government would negotiate a position that was not to our advantage? I make it very clear: we come to trade negotiations with a very good record and with very clean hands. We believe in market access, and anything we get is going to be of advantage to us. If we did not get a deal that is acceptable to the Australian government, to the Australian manufacturers, to Australian farmers and to the Australian film industry, why would you think for one moment we would conclude the deal? We would not and we will not. The government aim to deliver a world-class agreement.

As has been made very clear in the media this week, the penultimate stage or round in the negotiations is taking place in Canberra this week. We have a world-class FTA negotiating team, and I am very confident in what they will do. They have the support of the government in their efforts to deliver a world-class agreement. They do aim for finalisation this year. If you listened to what President Bush said last week, you would know that he reconfirmed the United States' commitment to this deadline. The Prime Minister told President Bush that Australia needs to see a good deal in agriculture for the FTA to be acceptable to us because we are a leading exporter and producer of agriculture. We produce five times the amount of food we can consume ourselves. We believe very much in providing access to Australian markets, but in return we require access to the world markets and we are prepared to work very hard to achieve that.

The Prime Minister and President Bush further agreed when they met last week in Canberra that following negotiations in Canberra this week Mr Vaile and the US Trade Representative, Bob Zoellick, would meet in the United States before Christmas. We need to wait and see what the US negotiators put on the table this week. It is very foolish to prejudge outcomes, because we all know in trade negotiations that what appear to be impossible and difficult sticking points can be worked out through goodwill and by trade-offs. But I think it is fair to say that Australia is aiming for improvements in the US offer across the board and that we expect to receive more detailed US requests on a range of issues. This has been quite a long process. There have been two full negotiating rounds, which are still to be completed. The government have been very keen to seek stakeholder and industry support. This is a very important negotiation from Australia's point of view. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is interesting to reflect that only a few days ago the President of the United States, George Bush Jr, was in this country and, of course, addressed a joint sitting of the houses of this parliament. We had protesters assembled outside the parliamentary building, protesting the decision of the US and Australian governments to embark on a war in Iraq. I recall very clearly the visit of the first President George Bush to Australia in 1991. I remind senators and the public that, also on that occasion, there were protesters assembled outside the parliament. There were a lot more of them than there were here last week. They were not protesting about any decision with respect to a war with Iraq; they were making their views felt about trade issues.

speech.para: In a rally organised by the National Farmers Federation, led by the then leader of the NFF, Graham Blight, protesters were in Canberra to stress their message to President Bushâand, through President Bush, to the US Congressâthat they wanted trade liberalisation. They wanted access to agricultural markets in the US. It is interesting, in the light of the debate we are having now and the questions that were addressed to Senator Cook, that today the NFF is once again making it clear to the governmentâthis time to a coalition governmentâthat they are not happy with the situation and with the view adopted by the United States with respect to this free trade agreement. As has been pointed out, we are at the penultimate stageâwe are really in the endgameâof these negotiations. The US President and the Australian Prime Minister have set a deadline of the end of this year to try to finalise the free trade agreement.

Senator Sandy Macdonald, Senator Hill and others have called into question the ALP's commitment to free trade. The Labor Party, when we were in government, promoted strongly the Uruguay Round. We had great successes in the Uruguay Round through the World Trade Organisation talks. Australia established the Cairns Group of agricultural nations and led it effectively. I recall that people like Graham Blight from the National Farmers Federation, and others from the agricultural and rural sectors of this countryânot the natural affiliates of the Labor Partyâwere fulsome in their praise of the efforts of Peter Cook and others as ministers for trade when we were in government. Of course, we were also the prime movers in establishing APEC. So, while ministers in this government ask what we did in 13 years, our record is incredibly strong in terms of what we did to promote trade liberalisation. This government is hanging its hat on establishing a free trade agreement with the US. But this is not just about the principle of a free trade agreement, because at the end of the day we all support free trade, providing the rules actually deliver free trade.

talk.start.para: âAre you sure?

âWe do, Senator Mason. We spent years battling the European Union and the US when we were in government, and we all know it is a hard slog. At the moment we have a situation where the US is, clearly, dictating the terms. Basically, agricultural industry in this country is being held to ransom in these talks. That is why the NFF are so critical of the position of this government, which looks as though it is about to acquiesce to US demands. What has this government done for agricultural trade in recent years? About the only significant thing it has done is to give 50,000 sheep to Eritrea. But there is more: not only did we give those sheep away but also we have provided feed and we threw in another $1 million on top. The whole fiasco, overseen by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Truss, will cost Australian farmers well in excess of $10 million. (Time expired)

âI had a very enjoyable Sunday. After going to church I read a book by Dennis GloverâI think he is Mr Crean's speechwriterâcalled Orwell's Australia: From Cold War to Culture Wars. The book is about the problem the Labor Party has between its two main support bases. On the one hand, there are the middle-class trendiesâthe chardonnay and cappuccino drinkers. On the other hand, of course, there are the battlers in the outer suburbs. So you have the swingers in the inner city and on theâ

âMr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Although I might be interested in the bookâI am sure I can get it out of the library if I need to read itâthere is an issue of relevance with respect to taking note. I am sure that Senator Mason will get to the point, but a preamble of more than a minute needs to address the issue.
âSenator Ludwig will resume his seat. There is no point of order. Senator Mason has been speaking for 51 seconds. I am sure that Senator Mason will be coming to the point very shortly.

âI think Senator Ludwig needs a bit more information about Labor Party policies. The problem with the Labor Party is that these two groups do not understand each other and the Labor Party needs an issue that will join the inner-city trendies with the outer-suburban battlers. Do you know what one of the issues is? Trade is one of the issues that will bring them both together, because you can stir up an awful amount of fear when you start talking about a free trade agreement with the United States. People get scared; they think there is going to be a problem with free trade. Let us talk about free trade for a second.

speech.para: Gough Whitlamâfor all his failures, for all his mistakes and despite a really appalling government in the 1970sâdid one thing that was right: he cut tariffs. Do you know why he cut tariffs? He said tariffs were a tax on the working class. Anyone who supports tariffs supports taxing the working class. When you talk about tariffs, the people who suffer the most are not the Labor Party and their union friends. It is not them. Do you know who it is? It is the poor, it is those in the developing countries and exporters. They are the ones who suffer the most. So when you get this sanctimonious stuff from the Australian Labor Party, this reflexive anti-Americanism that they always foster, it is based on this. The fact is Mr Whitlam knewâeven if the Labor Party today does not knowâthat tariffs hurt the workers. If just that point gets through this afternoon, perhaps this debate will have been worth while. Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and indeed Senator Cook, for all their failures, understood that message as well. So when people like this get out there and support all these losersâwho wrecked the World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattleâor at least play footsy with the far Left, all they are doing is causing workers and poor people to suffer. But of course that would not worry the Labor Party these days. It certainly would not worry all the inner-city swingers.

The reason Australia fundamentally has done so well in the last 20 years, particularly in the last seven years, is not just because of our marvellous policies. Despite the failures of the Labor Party, the one fundamental reason why Australia has done so well over the last 20 years, and particularly over the last seven, has been the reduction in tariffs. That is the principal reason. And now, of course, the opposition thinks: `Oh, we need an issue to belt the government with. Maybe we can just foster a little bit of fear.' You see, they need something to get back to their working-class constituency, because of their absolute, abject failure to connect with the working class.

talk.start.para: âThe battlers now support us, Senator Forshaw, because of your absolute failure to engage with them. That is absolutely the problem: your absolute misunderstanding of the tariff debate. The one thing Mr Whitlam got right in his appalling reign of government was that tariffs affect and disadvantage the working class. As soon as you understand that, Senator Forshaw, you will be on the road again.

âQuite often in this place we reflect on the importance of the Senate and why it should be broadcast more frequently. This is one of those moments where I am glad it is not, because I would hate the thought of my two-year-old daughter watching Sesame Street, then having Sesame Street being replaced by the performance we just saw.

âIt would keep her awake at night, Senator Mason, wondering what church you went to, wondering what was in that book, wondering what stimulated this reaction today. Maybe, unlike the cappuccino drinkers on our side, it was the cafe latte that you spent most of this morning drinking.
âSenator Mason, you have had your go.

âDo not call us `swingers', Senator Mason; we on this side of the parliament are not the swingers when it comes to trade issues. The Labor Party has had consistency on these issues: consistency in getting fair trade agreements, free trade agreements, agreements that are negotiated in the interests of the Australian people.
âFree trade is fair trade.
âKeep on swinging, Senator Mason. We are about getting a decent outcome for Australians; what you are about is that fawning, obsequious performance we saw last week.
âThis left-wing, reflexive anti-Americanism!
âSenator Mason.
âWill somebody give him a needle, pleaseâor will I pass over the valium?
âWhat would you like? He is so hyped up.
âSenator Mason and Senator Bolkus.

âI have worked it out: Senator Mason missed out on the rugby scrum last week. He was not there with Nigel Scullion and all the other boys in the pack and it is really showing today. The excitement and the disappointment of not being there have obviously affected him over the weekend. Senator Mason, the other thing I have to say to you after your contribution is that these people who are concerned about this issue are not losers. The farmers of Australia are not losers. The artists of Australia are not losers. People who have concerns with this issue should not be described by you, in a very deprecating and insulting way, as `losers'. We have people in the leadership of farm groups, industry groups, media industry groups, the sugar industry, labour groups and environmental groups who are really concerned about some of those things that you used to be concerned about before you took over government.

speech.para: Things have quietened down since last week. We are now starting to see the details of the hype that was being pursued by the Howard government. It is now time to look at the fine print. That is what Australians are doing, and what are they seeing? Australians have increasing concern about where this trade agreement is going.

talk.start.para: âWhere is the proof of that?

âAustralians' concern goes to the issue of sovereignty, Senator Ferrisâyou set up a committee of this parliamentâconcern about treaties and the application of Australian sovereignty through treaties. Show some concern about this particular treaty when it comes to the sovereignty of Australia. Their concerns go to social policy, cultural policy and economic policy. Australians realise that they have a fawning, obsequious government, not concernedânot reallyâand not understanding that there is a major economic power balance in these trade negotiations. They are concerned that this government does not see that, as my colleague Senator Conroy showed, the immediate benefits to Australia are likely to be limited. They can see a government that cannot see what the rest of Australia, the rest of America and the rest of the world can seeâthat is, real concessions, particularly in the farm sector, will not be realised, particularly in an election year in the USA. President Bush relies on those southern farming states for his support. He cannot afford to lose them. Do you reckon he is going to shaft his farmers in the interests of ours? Absolutely no way at all. The farm sector in this country is smart enough to see that, but their representatives in this place call them `losers'. That is the sort of debate we have from the other side of the parliament. They are falling over themselves to shake President Bush's hand and, in the meantime, are about to make major concessions to the US.

speech.para: Senator Hill and I know what the Americans are like when it comes to international negotiations. We were at The Hague conference on reducing greenhouse gas emissions a little while ago. We could see that, on the one hand, while the rest of the world was trying to get an agreement on environmental grounds to protect the environment, the Americans were trying to find every opportunity possible to introduce non-tariff subsidies for their farm sector. As Minister for Consumer Affairs just a few years ago, I took a decision to ban the import of smokeless tobacco into this country. Do you reckon the reaction we got from the US Congress was reasonable and rational? To some of them, it was the end of the alliance as they saw it. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Hill) to a question without notice asked today relating to human rights in China.

speech.para: I hope that Senator Hill remains, because I am about to say something positive about the minister's response, particularly his second response. I am very disappointed that Senator Mason has not remained, because I was going to speak about the danger of moral relativism and some of the problems that some people in the country have in equating human rights problems of Western regimes with the human rights problems in China. It is a point that Senator Mason frequently makesâin fact, he seems to make it every time he stands up to speak, and I was surprised that he did not manage to fit it in this timeâwhich is consistent with what happened last week during the visits of the two presidents to Australia. Unfortunately, we had significant public protests on the Thursday against some of the policies of the Bush regime in the USAâprotests that the Democrats support and concerns that the Democrats share, I might say. But, on the Friday, during the visit by a president who is the representative of a regime that has human rights abuses far in excess of those of the United States, there were minimal protests from the general public and I think that was very unfortunate. It sends a message that the public are more concerned about the human rights and the broader record of the US regime than they are about the Chinese regime, even though there is clearly a greater degree of human rights abuses by the Chinese government over many years.

I would have thought that Senator Mason would be applauding the fact that that discrepancy has been brought to public opinion and applauding the fact that President Huâwho is still, let us not forget, the heir of Chairman Mao, whom he goes to great lengths to abuse and criticise, quite rightlyâwas in Australia last week. Yet there was not as much public outrage about the degree of human rights abuses of that regime as there was towards the US regime. The Democrats have been consistent on this issue. We expressed strong concerns both in the lead-up to and on the day of President Hu's visit and subsequently about the human rights abuses of the Chinese regime.

I note the minister's extra information that he provided at the end of question time saying that the Prime Minister did raise human rights issues in his one-on-one discussions with President Hu, when he was here in Australia last Friday. He did not indicate what issues he raised or in what way they were raised. Nonetheless, the fact that human rights dialogue was noted and raised needs to be welcomed. The minister's extra answer seemed to suggest that the issue of Tibet was specifically raised and the Democrats are very pleased about that. We also would note and support some of the positive advances that have been made in recent years, such as the dialogue that China has now initiated with representatives of the Dalai Lama regarding the future of Tibet. This was raised by the representatives of the Tibetan community and supporters of the Tibetan cause in a letter that was signed by a number of parliamentarians, prior to the arrival of President Hu, indicating our support for those initial advances by the Chinese regime and encouraging them to go further. However, it has to be drawn from the minister's two answers that broader issues of human rights abuses in China were not raised. It is good to emphasise the positive and, as the minister said, give credit where it is due, but that should not be used as an excuse to sweep what are still very extreme human rights abuses under the carpetâhuman rights abuses that are much wider than the issue of Tibet, although I do not seek to diminish that issue at all.

Let us look at some of the facts of the issues which are affecting not just Chinese families but Australian families. In the weeks leading up to President Hu's visit, the Democrats met with Australians whose families are being subjected to persecution in ChinaâAustralians who live in daily fear for the welfare of their mothers, fathers, brothers and sisters. More than 1,600 people have been tortured or beaten to death in China and more than 500 people have been given prison sentences of over 20 years, simply for exercising their freedom of belief and their freedom of religion. This is unacceptable. It has to be raised. We cannot ignore these issues simply because there are trade opportunities. The Democrats support exploring trade opportunities, but that should not be used as an excuse to not raise uncomfortable or important issues. It is unfortunate. Indeed, it should be condemned that the Prime Minister did not raise these issues. He did not even mention the positive aspects of humanâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time for the debate has expired.

âby leaveâI want to deal with the process of the annual dialogue between Australia and China on human rights. In 1997 the Chinese threatened trade sanctions unless we removed human rights from the focus of the bilateral dialogue and did not involve ourselves in UN discussions relating to violations of human rights in China. That is the genesis of the government now saying that human rights in China is an area of discussion we should not be involved in. We are already involved in it. A number of academics have studied the process of the annual dialogue. They have shown that, generally speaking, there are no publicly stated benchmarks and an irregularâor non-existentâprogram of evaluation. There is very little transparency in the process. Partners are more open about claiming positive results, although it is often hard to link these results directly to the dialogue.
